headline: RAILSTON: Liverpool could hurt Manchester United in the summer transfer window
body: Marcus Rashford admitted he would like to play with Barcelona star Lamine Yamal last month.
Rashford fluttered his eyelashes at the Catalan club, but they seem to fancy another forward.
Luis Diaz has been heavily linked with a move away from Liverpool this summer and his name continues to crop up alongside Rashford's when Barcelona's transfer business is discussed.
Barcelona are in the market for a forward and Diaz and Rashford are both valued between £40million and £50m, although the similarities stop there between Diaz's situation at Liverpool and Rashford.
Manchester United are desperate to sell Rashford after his relationship with Ruben Amorim broke down, while Liverpool are hopeful of retaining Diaz amid talks over a new contract.
Diaz has admitted that he's open to a new challenge, though, and one of the most likely destinations for Rashford would be taken off the table if the Colombian international switched to Camp Nou.
Barcelona cannot afford to sign both players. Liverpool cashing in on an offer from Barcelona for Diaz would end Rashford's hopes of playing in La Liga and deny United a convenient £40m sale.
Liverpool winning the Premier League was bad enough for United supporters last season, but they could potentially block Rashford's move, which is important to unlock funds for Amorim.
However, the reports linking Rashford with a move to Barcelona are not going away and their sporting director, Deco, went on record about Rashford when he spoke to BBC Sport last month.

Deco insisted Barcelona will "not sell our best players". He said Barcelona were in the market for "two, three or four signings", without needing to enter the market "like crazy" thanks to a solid base.

And when asked if Barcelona's plans included the option of signing Rashford, or Liverpool forward Diaz, he added: "We have been focusing on renewing contracts, after that, we'll discuss players to come.

"Of course, these two players, like you mentioned, they are good but have contracts in their clubs, so we won't speak because it's not fair. But when you decide to go to the market, for sure, we find some names. In my opinion, we don't need to bring many players."

Deco continued: "When I speak with the agents of the players, everyone wants to come or stay. So this is important. The image of the club is still good. We are proud because Barcelona is still such a big club, and the way we are playing football makes players want to come."
In the meantime, Rashford has returned to Carrington to train on his own in the afternoons, despite the club granting extra time to the players who want to explore a departure.

Rashford is also without a squad shirt number after United decided to give the No.10 shirt to new signing Matheus Cunha. Some fans believe that was disrespectful, and others just want to see Rashford out the door.
Regardless of those different opinions splitting the fanbase, it's sad to see the most successful United academy graduate of recent times end his time at his boyhood club on a sour note.
Rashford will hope for a move to Barcelona to turn a negative situation into a positive, but Liverpool could have an influence this summer and essentially hurt United in the transfer window.

headline: Mbeumo, wantaway five, £7.62m boost - Seven transfer deals Manchester United can complete next week
body: Manchester United are back in action in just six days' time as they take on Leeds United in their first pre-season friendly in Stockholm's Friends Arena.

Matheus Cunha could make his first appearance in United colours following his £62.5million move from Wolves, while teenage left-back Diego Leon could also be involved for the first time as a United player.

Ahead of his first full season in charge, Reds boss Ruben Amorim would have hoped for more progress in the transfer market by this stage but it could be a busy week ahead of United's trip to the Swedish capital.
With that in mind, we have taken a look at seven United transfers that could happen this week.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
It has already become the long-running saga of United's transfer window but they are hopeful they can make some progress on the deal to sign Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford this week.
United are desperate for the Cameroon international to join and the 25-year-old is keen on the move to Old Trafford.
However, United have two bids rejected by the Bees for a player who scored 20 Premier League goals last season and will be keen to ensure their third bid sees them make a breakthrough.
For United to make further progress on incoming transfers, they need to make some headway with bringing in funds from player sales.

United confirmed nine days ago that Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Antony, Alejandro Garnacho and Tyrell Malacia had asked to leave the club but there has been no progress made on any of their departures.
Should that change this week it could well help to kickstart some more incoming business.
After pocketing some money off Anthony Elanga's transfer from Nottingham Forest to Newcastle United, Manchester United will be keeping a keen eye on events at Real Madrid this week.
Los Blancos are set to sign Benfica left-back Alvaro Carreras for £43million - a £38million profit on the £5million they paid to sign the Spaniard from United last summer.
United are entitled to 20% of that profit after inserting a sell-on clause in the deal and stand to inherit £7.62million once the deal is completed.

headline: Manchester United hoping to complete exciting double transfer this summer
body: Manchester United are in talks to sign two promising young midfielders this summer.
Fulham youngster Seth Ridgeon, who captains England Under-17s, has attracted interest from United.
Tyrese Noubissie is set to depart Manchester City and could switch allegiances in Manchester.
Ridgeon is regarded as one of the country's most exciting young attacking midfielders and his future at Craven Cottage is uncertain, which has placed United, City, Chelsea and Liverpool on alert.
Noubissie, a central midfielder, could be lured to Carrington by the promise of a clear pathway to the first-team, and United are hopeful of adding both young talents to their academy.

United are always on the lookout for the best young talent to add to their youth ranks. Brexit impacted which youngsters they can sign, which means recruiting players from within Britain has become common.
Nick Cox (head of the academy) and Luke Fedorenko (head of academy recruitment) have overseen the academy recruitment drive and play a crucial role in youth transfers, which can be delicate.
United have already sealed the signing of Harley Emsden-James, 16, from Southampton this summer.
The young defender has played for England at youth level and will join United's academy. Southampton will receive compensation and Jason Wilcox has also played an important role in the move.

headline: Five things spotted in Manchester United training as two new signings involved
body: Manchester United have enjoyed a week of training in tropical conditions at Carrington.
Hot weather has swept across the United Kingdom as Ruben Amorim prepares his players for their opening pre-season friendly of the summer against Leeds in Stockholm on July 19.
All of the squad have now reported back to Carrington, with the exception of those who wish to explore a move away this summer, and spirits seemed high in the training footage released by club media.
So here are five things we spotted in training at Carrington...
Altay Bayindir, Casemiro, Diogo Dalot, Patrick Dorgu, Bruno Fernandes, Manuel Ugarte, Rasmus Hojlund and Chido Obi all reported back to Carrington for pre-season on Thursday morning.
The players who were on international duty at the end of last season were given extra time to enjoy a break.
The 'welcome back tunnel' has become a tradition for players who return from injury at Carrington, but it was rolled out for those who returned from international duty on a sun-kissed pitch.
Hojlund spectacularly regressed last season, scoring just four goals in the Premier League, and a move to Italian club Inter Milan could be on the cards in the summer transfer window.

It feels more likely that Hojlund will stay and fight for a starting place, though. The 22-year-old recently played down suggestions he could leave United when he spoke to Danish media and his finishing must improve if he stays.
Perhaps that's why United included footage of Hojlund finding the back of the net on three successive occasions in a training drill, with the striker blasting past Radek Vitek.
Earlier this month, new signing Diego Leon promised he would "kill it" in pre-season to impress Amorim.
United agreed a £3.3million fee, rising to £7m with add-ons, with Cerro Porteno and Leon is expected to be assessed in the coming weeks before a final decision is made on his next steps.
Leon is clearly not short of confidence and it will be impressive if he can earn a first-team role.
Could this be the season that Shea Lacey makes a highly anticipated first-team debut? Followers of the academy will hope so, although Lacey is yet to make an appearance for the Under-21s.

That has been circumstantial - Lacey was wrapped up in cotton wool at the end of last season - but it would be unheard of for an academy player to make a first-team debut without playing for the U21s.
Nonetheless, Lacey is not an ordinary talent and it's exciting to see him around the first-team set up.
Amad celebrated his 23rd birthday on Friday and was treated to a rendition of 'Happy Birthday'.
The winger's teammates and club staff serenaded the popular Amad as he clapped along himself.
Amad was one of the only players to emerge from last season with credit. He was superb until sustaining an ankle injury in training in February and should be a key player again in 2025/2026.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Viktor Gyokeres bombshell, Emi Martinez boost, Bryan Mbeumo wait
body: Hello and welcome back to the Manchester United transfer blog on Sunday, July 13.

We are now less than a week out from United returning to the pitch as they seek to put right the wrongs from last season in the Premier League. As we edge ever closer to the serious stuff beginning in mid-August, United will be hoping to complete some more business in the next couple of weeks to stand them in better stead.

Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres has been heavily linked with a move to United this summer but that opportunity had looked to be fizzling out when Arsenal increased their interest. However, negotiations have hit a wall with United potentially in a position to capitalise.

Andre Onana's hamstring injury has thrust the goalkeeper conversation back to the forefront this weekend. Botafogo's John Victor has been named as a potential target for the Reds to strengthen that position.

Finally, overarching all of this is the talk surrounding Bryan Mbeumo and the continued negotiations with Brentford. As of yet, the Reds have still been unable to reach an agreement with the Bees over his signature.
Keep across all this and more from United in our dedicated blog below...
Join us tomorrow for more Manchester United transfer news.
We'll have you covered ahead of United's first pre-season friendly on Saturday.
Manchester United look set to miss out on Viktor Gyokeres this summer following news that Arsenal have finally reached an agreement with Sporting CP.

After agreeing a five-year contract with Gyokeres and his camp, the north Londoners now look to have finally agreed a deal with Sporting CP to get their man. The Athletic have reported that Arsenal are now taking the final steps in negotiations with the Portuguese champions and are processing to get the deal done.
Reports in Italy have claimed that Jadon Sancho has an agreement in principle with Juventus.

Tuttosport have claimed that Man United and the Serie A side remain in talks after Sanco agreed a four-year deal in Turin worth over €5million per season. The deal includes an option for a further year.
Atalanta defender Giorgio Scalvini has been strongly linked with a move to the Premier League this summer.
Newcastle and Tottenham said said to be keen but according to The i Paper has suggested that Man United are showing interest in the highly-talented centre-back.
Atalanta want more than £50m for the defender and are hoping to tie Scalvini down to a new contract.
Man United have made 'initial enquiries' into signing Bayern Munich and Portugal midfielder Joao Palhinha this summer.
A report by Caught Offside has claimed that United are 'maintaining communication' with Bayern this summer with Palhinha's future at the club unclear.
The report states that Bayern would demand between £25million and £30million, a lower fee to the one he signed for the club a year ago.
Manchester United have been told to complete the signing of Dusan Vlahovic this summer ''immediately'.
Former Juve striker Darko Kovacevic has insisted he should seek pastures new with haste, and given talk around a move to the Premier League, his wish may come true.
"I’d say to Dušan to move on immediately," the 51-year-old told Gazzetta dello Sport.

"It’s not easy to leave Juventus, I say this from personal experience, but sometimes you have to get back in the game to get back to being happy and at the top. Someone like Vlahović must always be a starter, at Juventus or elsewhere."
United's nutritional department has received a significant shake-up.

Omar Meziane left his position as first-team head chef in December to join McLaren's Formula One team, and Thomas Maynard left his role as first-team performance nutritionist at the end of last season.
The department is now essentially brand new after the appointments of Will Carvalho (head performance chef), Marcus Hannon (head of sports nutrition) and Filipe Sousa (first-team nutritionist).
MORE HERE.
According to Fabrizio Romano, the structure of United's add-ons for Mbeumo is currently obstructing a deal being agreed.
It is understood that while a £62.5m total fee was being offered, the Bees were unhappy about the manner of the £7.5m add-ons.
The Brentford camp are believed to be feeling like those add-ons are too difficult to achieve and they need those to be more realistic before they agree to sell their talisman.
It is looking like United are going to be clearing house of their goalkeepers this summer with Radek Vitek the latest to be linked with a move away.
The Sun understands Championship club Millwall are interested on the 21-year-old who has just left Austrian side BW Linz after a season-long loan spell.
However, United's young shot stopper is not the only player of interest for Millwall with veteran goalkeeper Tim Krul and Everton's Joao Virginia both thought to be of interest.
According to The Mirror, Altay Bayindir's agent is in Manchester to discuss his client's future.
The meeting comes amid talk that United are interested in signing a new goalkeeper, in particular John from Botafogo.
Bayindir reportedly rejected offers from Europe in January and new approaches have been building in recent weeks for his services.
A move for the 29-year-old would be considered a risk after he has only featured once in Europe - a short loan spell at Real Valladolid in the 2023/24 season.
Since moving to Botafogo in January 2024, John has managed to become a regular for the Brazilian club.
He played for them in the Club World Cup this summer, notably keeping a clean sheet in the group stages against European champions PSG.
According to Goal Brasil, Botafogo are preparing for the departure of their goalkeeper John Victor in the summer transfer window.
It is claimed that in light of Onana's injury, United have submitted an offer for the shot stopper.
Onana has suffered a hamstring injury and will be in a race against the clock to be fit again for the start of the Premier League season against Arsenal.
As they look to continue strengthening for the future, MEN Sport understands that United want to complete the signings of England U17s captain Seth Ridgeon and Tyrese Noubissie.
Ridgeon is currently on the books of Fulham while Noubissie is expected to leave Manchester City's academy this summer.
United have already sealed the signing of Harley Emsden-James, 16, from Southampton this summer.
MORE HERE.
According to The Mirror, Rashford is set to hold talks with United this coming week to discuss his future.
The forward is thought to be in limbo after being informed that he is not in manager Amorim's plans.
However, his current wage is proving a stumbling block to allowing him to depart with a loan move now considered to be the most likely option for him.
Earlier today we brought you reports that Garnacho had rejected Al Nassr this summer.
Now, it appears that Rashford has also rejected a lucrative approach from Saudi Arabia.
Mundo Deportivo understands that Rashford is uninterested in moving to the unnamed Saudi Pro League club with his focus remaining on a move to Barcelona.
Well, there is still a chance that United can benefit from Arsenal stalling in negotiations.
Journalist Ben Jacobs told The United Stand recently that he remains open to an Old Trafford move.
The facts as he sees them are that Gyokeres invited interest from Arsenal and never explicitly stated that he did not want to sign for United.
So if United can somehow stump up the asking price for Gyokeres, that deal could be back on.
Amidst all of this, Gyokeres has declared his desire to be playing Premier League football in the 2025/26 season.
Speaking to L'Equipe, the Swede said:

Maybe [I will leave]. That’s football, you never know. I don’t think about it; we’ll see what happens. If something happens, it will. The most important thing for me is to play for a club that really wants me. It’s one of the biggest leagues (Premier League) in Europe. I spent several years there without being able to play a single match. So, of course, it’s something I’d like to do. It would be great revenge.
According to the Daily Telegraph, Garnacho has rejected the chance to sign permanently for Al Nassr this summer.
It is believed that Ronaldo's team tried to persuade the Argentine to join them for their Saudi Pro League title pursuit.
However, Garnacho's aim is to stay in the Premier League and is unwilling to move to the Middle East at this stage.
There is a clear reason behind that, and it all stems from the valuation Sporting have for Gyokeres.
The Swede was under the impression that should a bid of £52m plus £8.67m in add-ons was to be submitted, he would be allowed to leave the Lisbon club.
While Varandas agrees that holding out for his £85m release clause would not be possible, he is also unwilling to let the striker leave for that little.
It is believed that Sporting's asking price is £60.67m plus £8.67m in add-ons and, as of yet, no club has reached that valuation.
In the latest twist in the Gyokeres saga, the striker has been issued with disciplinary action from Sporting after failing to arrive for pre-season training.
Sporting president Frederico Varandas sent a clear message to the striker on Saturday:

We're calm. Everything can be solved with the closure of the market, a hefty fine and an apology to the group. If they don't want to pay Viktor's fair market value, we'll be very comfortable with that for the next three years. If the geniuses who are devising this strategy think that this puts pressure on me to make it easier for him to leave, not only are they completely wrong, but they are also making it more complicated for the player to leave. No one is above the interests of the club. Whoever they are.
Hello and welcome back to the United transfer blog this Sunday morning.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be keeping you across the latest United news throughout the morning.
Temperatures may be soaring outside and the transfer window drama surrounding this man is certainly heating up too...

headline: Man United handed huge Ollie Watkins transfer boost as £69m deal emerges
body: Ollie Watkins has been linked with a summer move to Manchester United. Ruben Amorim's side are in the market for a new No.9 and the Aston Villa forward is among those on the club's shortlist.

Watkins, 29, signed for Villa in a £33million deal from Brentford in September 2020. Since then, the 18-time England international has cemented himself as one of the top strikers in the Premier League. He has scored 87 goals and provided 42 assists in 223 appearances during his time at Villa Park.

However, Watkins could leave Villa this summer after growing frustrated with his game time last season. He was left "fuming" after Marcus Rashford took his place up front for some important matches in April, including the two-legged Champions League quarter-final against Paris Saint-Germain.
This followed a spell earlier in the season where Jhon Duran was preferred as the lone centre forward. But Watkins did regain his spot after Duran was sold to Al-Nassr in January for around £65m.
United are among those interested in a move for Watkins and their pursuit of the former Exeter City man could be boosted as Villa eye a blockbuster deal for Porto hitman Samu Aghehowa.

According to Portuguese outlet A Bola, Porto are considering selling Aghehowa after just one season. The 21-year-old signed for the Primeira Liga outfit in a permanent move from Atletico Madrid last summer.
But, despite netting 27 goals in 45 games for Porto in 2024/25, Francesco Farioli's side are weighing up cashing in on Aghehowa and making a considerable profit on the £23.3m they paid to sign him.
It's added that Villa have expressed an interest in signing Aghehowa and have identified the Spaniard as a possible replacement for Watkins. Porto value Melilla-born Aghehowa at £69m.

Aghehowa scored twice against United in the Europa League last October and he could do serious damage in the Premier League. Only Sporting CP's Viktor Gyokeres (39), who has been linked with a move to United this summer, netted more in Portugal's top tier than Aghehowa (19) last season.

Indeed, should Villa opt to sign Aghehowa, Watkins could therefore be allowed to leave, opening up a potential move to United. Amorim's side want a new No.9 and the Villa forward could be the perfect man to strengthen their attack, having scored 17 goals and added 14 assists in 54 games last term.

headline: Viktor Gyokeres delivers Man United bombshell as final transfer steps taken
body: Manchester United look set to miss out on Viktor Gyokeres this summer following news that Arsenal have finally reached an agreement with Sporting CP.

Gyokeres has been one of the strikers tipped to join United this summer due to his connection with Ruben Amorim. The Reds boss signed the Swede from Coventry City in 2023 and he has become one of Europe's most prolific goalscorers.

In two seasons in Portugal, the 27-year-old has scored 97 goals in 102 appearances. However, United haven't been alone in the race to sign him and it now looks like Arsenal will bolster their centre-forward ranks.

The Gunners have been heavily linked with the striker for some time and their interest dates back further than United's. Mikel Arteta is desperate to strengthen his attack after the lack of a centre-forward played a big part in his side missing out on the Premier League title.

After agreeing a five-year contract with Gyokeres and his camp, the north Londoners now look to have finally agreed a deal with Sporting CP to get their man. The Athletic have reported that Arsenal are now taking the final steps in negotiations with the Portuguese champions and are processing to get the deal done.
Up until now, talks have been delayed by Sporting's president Frederico Varandas seemingly refusing to see out the gentleman's agreement to allow him to depart for around £59million.

Now, the Premier League side have made 'formal advances' over terms to close the deal. It's said negotiations were reignited earlier this weekend and the communication between the two parties has improved.

The deal will leave United at square one in their bid to sign a centre-forward. With Gyokeres moving to the Emirates Stadium and Victor Osimhen the subject of strong interest from Galatasaray, Amorim is faced with the reality of exploring alternatives.

headline: Man United one step away from unleashing three players with £26m transfer as bid rejected
body: Since Manchester United lost the Europa League final to Tottenham on May 21, talk has materialised day-by-day calling for a desperate overhaul of the playing squad.
Ruben Amorim's first 'phase' at Old Trafford has been faced with countless problems ranging from player fall-out, disappointing results and now a lack of some much-needed transfer business.

So far, United have bought just Matheus Cunha. The Brazilian's £62.5million release clause was triggered at the start of June and he's already been introduced to his teammates at Carrington. But, despite Amorim admitting a number of times that his team requires attention, United have not yet acted.

Their interest in Bryan Mbeumo has been ongoing for well over a month now with two bids turned down by Brentford. Any hope that the 25-year-old would be part of United's pre-season squad have rapidly dwindled and the apparent lack of a third offer has cast doubts over an actual deal happening.

Whilst the main focus for Jason Wilcox and the recruitment team at United is to sign Mbeumo sooner rather than later, the Reds have other positions that need strengthening. One of them areas at centre-forward with United expected to sign a striker with better goalscoring prowess than Rasmus Hojlund.

However, a new midfielder has also been tipped to come in. Amorin's dream front three of Mbeumo, Cunha and a striker means Bruno Fernandes is expected to be play in one of the two central midfielder spots. One issue Amorim has, though, is that there isn't an obvious candidate to partner him.

Manuel Ugarte and Casemiro both featured heavily for United last term with Kobbie Mainoo's season being stagnated by injuries. The likes of Ederson, Wilfried Ndidi and Douglas Luiz have all been linked with coming to the club but Palmeiras' Richard Rios is a name that doesn't seem to be fading from United's catalogue of reported transfer targets.

Rios has flourished at the Brazilian outfit and is one of the many players to come away from the Club World Cup with a glowing reputation. The box-to-box midfielder has been mentioned for a couple of weeks now but reports in Italy have suggested that United have finally entered the race.

Gazzetta dello Sport has claimed that the Reds have stepped up their interest in the 25-year-old and have taken 'concrete steps' towards signing him. Roma have recently failed with a £22m bid for the Colombian, falling short of Palmeiras' £26m asking price.

It leaves the door open for United to swoop in and add him to Amorim's squad. Many may question the Reds' need for a midfielder of Rios' profile but having an energetic character alongside a technician and creator like Fernandes could be a perfect piece of United's puzzle.

Heavy emphasis is on the two wing-backs in Amorim's system. Getting Patrick Dorgu and Diogo Dalot, or Amad, wide and forward is pivotal to United gaining success. The problem they've had at times is that the lack of energy and connection in the middle of the park has left them short when wing-backs go forward.

Rios' arrival wouldn't guarantee an immediate starting place at Old Trafford. However, there is reason for the energetic and combative midfielder to be signed. Not only would he add the liveliness required to free Fernandes to pull the string in the final third, but he would provide the defensive stability to allow the wing-backs to stretch the pitch and cause havoc out wide.

headline: Manchester United appoint five new staff members as Carrington plan takes shape
body: Manchester United's nutritional department has received a significant shake-up.

Omar Meziane left his position as first-team head chef in December to join McLaren's Formula One team, and Thomas Maynard left his role as first-team performance nutritionist at the end of last season.
The department is now essentially brand new after the appointments of Will Carvalho (head performance chef), Marcus Hannon (head of sports nutrition) and Filipe Sousa (first-team nutritionist).
Carvalho joined United from Brighton, where he worked as the executive performance chef from 2013. He previously worked for Scottish Rugby, Gloucester Rugby and Brazil’s women’s team.
Hannon joins from Qatar's Football Association, but he has previous Premier League experience after working as the head of nutrition at Aston Villa between 2020 and 2022.
Sousa previously worked for Portuguese clubs Vitoria Sport Clube, F.C. Famalicao and FC Vizela.
Furthermore, United are in the process of hiring a senior sous chef and an academy nutritionist.
Hanna Zouggari (women’s first-team nutritionist) and Rachel Fleck (women’s academy performance nutritionist) have also been appointed.

United's job advert for senior sous chef read: "As senior sous chef at Manchester United’s world-class training ground, you will play a key leadership role within the culinary team, supporting the head chef in delivering exceptional, nutritionally balanced meals tailored for elite athletes and staff.
"This role demands culinary excellence, operational discipline, and a deep understanding of dietary requirements in a high-performance sports environment.

"The senior sous chef will assist in managing day-to-day kitchen operations, driving innovation in menu development, maintaining the highest food safety standards, in a motivated team committed to performance nutrition, service, and quality."
United's players have reported back to Carrington for the beginning of pre-season and will play their opening friendly of the summer against Leeds in Stockholm, Sweden on July 19.

headline: Man United finally get green light for Andre Onana replacement transfer as deal 'agreed'
body: Manchester United may have to explore the possibility of signing a new goalkeeper this summer following Andre Onana's hamstring injury.

United's number one will miss United's pre-season tour of the United States after suffering a hamstring problem. It's expected that the 29-year-old will still travel Stateside but the focus will be on recovery.

Altay Bayindir is expected to take his spot in Ruben Amorim's starting XI during pre-season but the Turkey international's future at the club has been in doubt. It's believed that the goalkeeper's agent has been at Carrington this week to discuss the £4.3million signing's future at the club.

With Onana's injury and the prospect of Bayindir leaving the club in search of first-team football, United are considering a move for a new goalkeeper - to replace Onana as first-choice or Bayindir as the back-up.

United are also in the market for other players and their budget not being at the level of their rivals, players like John Victor from Botafogo have been linked with a move to Manchester. Goal Brazil has reported that United are now ready to sign the Brazilian for his £6million release clause after his Club World Cup performances.

However, Emiliano Martinez continues to be heavily tipped to become United's brand new number one. Talks to sign the Aston Villa shot-stopper have already been held with Martinez said to be open to a move to Old Trafford.

His £40m asking price has meant any potential move is yet to be made but the 32-year-old continues to be linked with the club. Martinez's name could be a one that United re-consider in the coming weeks after Aston Villa moved closer to finalising an agreement for a new goalkeeper of their own.

The Athletic has reported that Brest's Marco Bizot is expected to move to Villa Park this summer for a low-cost fee. He's anticipated to come in as the club's No.2 but uncertainty over Martinez's future means Unai Emery now has a short-term fix.

BBC Sport has reported that Bizot is set to arrive to the United Kingdom soon and complete his move to the Premier League side. Personal terms are thought to be a 'formality' meaning a deal could be close to completion.

Martinez has addressed his future this summer, suggesting he isn't sure if he will be staying in the Midlands. “My future? I don’t know,” he said. “I come here to play for the national team, and that’s the only thing that matters to me right now," he said when away with his national team
“Do I want to move to a new club? The transfer window just opened, so there’s still a long way to go.”

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United confirm injury blow ahead of USA pre-season tour
body: Manchester United goalkeeper Andre Onana has suffered a hamstring injury after reporting for pre-season.
Onana has responded well to initial treatment and will travel to the USA this month with the squad, but his participation in the Premier League Summer Series has been thrown in doubt.
United will travel across the Atlantic to face West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton in the States. Onana's injury means Altay Bayindir could be the first-choice goalkeeper during the three-game tour.
Onana's future at Old Trafford became a talking point last season and it remains to be seen whether Ruben Amorim now believes it's necessary to sign a new goalkeeper in the summer window.
Onana had been preparing under the assumption he will still be at United for 2025/2026.
The Cameroon international made an impressive start to last season, but his form plummeted and he made high-profile mistakes against Nottingham Forest, Viktoria Plzen and Lyon.
Although Bayindir made 10 appearances last season as Amorim granted him more opportunities, he conceded 18 goals and failed to convince as a second-choice goalkeeper option.
Tom Heaton is the third-choice goalkeeper and recently signed a one-year contract extension.

headline: Player agent 'flies in' for Man United transfer talks as summer move could be sealed
body: Manchester United's back-up goalkeeper Altay Bayindir is reportedly set to welcome his agent to the city this week for talks surrounding his future at the club.

Bayindir arrived at Old Trafford in the summer of 2023 as United's then manager Erik ten Hag looked for a back-up to first choice Andre Onana. In his first season in Manchester, the Turkish shot stopper made just one appearance against Newport County in the FA Cup as Ten Hag was reluctant to swap out the Cameroonian.

Last season, with Onana's form still shaky and Ten Hag removed from power, Bayindir was given a few more opportunities to impress. However, his performances were inconsistent albeit his performance against Arsenal in the FA Cup in January was impressive.

Despite Ruben Amorim being more confident to trust Bayindir, he remained firmly a second choice and now even that position is in doubt. The Mirror reported on Sunday that United are interested in signing another goalkeeper this summer with Botafogo's John thought to be high on their shortlist.

If he was to arrive, Bayindir's position at Old Trafford would start to look even more uncertain. MEN Sport understands Onana has received reassurances from the United backroom staff that he remains part of the plans and Tom Heaton signed a new contract to be third choice.

As such, The Mirror reports that Bayindir's agent Sefa Seyrek has flown to Manchester to discuss his client's position at the club. It is believed that the 27-year-old fended off interest from Europe for his signature in January as he did not want to leave.
In recent weeks, that interest has resurfaced again and Bayindir could, this time, welcome such an approach.

headline: Man United transfer latest amid Bryan Mbeumo talks and fresh Ruben Amorim blow
body: Manchester United still have plenty of work to do in the summer transfer window having signed just two players so far.

The Reds activated Matheus Cunha's £62.5million release clause early last month, bringing the Wolves forward to Old Trafford on a five-year deal with an option for an extra year. Paraguayan left-back Diego Leon has also joined the club, but may be loaned out.

The Reds are also yet to shift anyone from their squad, despite Marcus Rashford, Antony, Tyrell Malacia, Jadon Sancho, and Alejandro Garnacho deemed surplus to requirements by Amorim. United travel to the Swedish capital of Stockholm to face Leeds on July 19, before their tour of the United States and will be hoping to conclude more transfer business by then.
Below is a look at the latest reports surrounding United's potential transfer activity with the summer window closing on Monday, September 1 at 7 pm BST.
United's initial bid of £55m did not tempt the Bees, who are said to be holding out for a figure closer to £63m.

The Telegraph report that goalkeeper Andre Onana has been ruled out of United's pre-season tour with a hamstring injury. It is reported the Cameroonian sustained the blow in training at Carrington this week and could be sidelined for 'six to eight weeks' following an early assessment.
It iis understood that the Reds are still looking to sign a new striker after missing out on Liam Delap to Premier League rivals Chelsea.

Another No.9 heavily linked in Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres also looks set to join one of United's top-flight rivals, with Arsenal said to be his preference. Hugo Ekitike, Ollie Watkins and Moise Kean have also been linked.

Several short-term options are also reportedly being considered, including free agents - Jamie Vardy, Callum Wilson and Dominic Calvert-Lewin. The Reds' need for a reliable goalscoring striker is much-needed after netting just 44 times in the league last term.
The Independent's Miguel Delaney has claimed in his latest newsletter that United's next priority will be a new central midfielder once a deal for Mbeumo is agreed.

"There's been a lot of noise about Manchester United and strikers but the feeling is that the next priority once Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo is secured - it seems to get "closer" every day - is a central midfielder," he said.
"There is interest in Sporting's Martin Hjulmand, Bayern Munich's Joao Palhinha and Palmeiras' Richard Rios. As almost goes without saying, they of course need to sell first.

"Bayern may be in the same situation, however, which is what makes the Palhinha interest intriguing. The lamentable injury to Jamal Musiala means they have to go back into the market, and that could create a few openings."

headline: Mason Greenwood sends former Man United star message as £52m transfer decision confirmed
body: Former Manchester United forward Mason Greenwood has sent a message to ex-teammate Anthony Elanga after he completed his move to Newcastle United. The Sweden international made the cross-Premier League switch to the North East for £55million to become Eddie Howe's first signing of the summer.

The 23-year-old signed a five-year deal and it has been suggested that United included a clause where the club receive 15 per cent of the profits from his next sale. As a result, Ruben Amorim's side reportedly banked around £6million for Elanga's move from Nottingham Forest, having made the City Ground switch in 2023.
Elanga shrugged off his disappointment at failing to break into Erik ten Hag's side to become a key member of Nuno Espirito Santo's side as they ended their wait to qualify for European football.
After completing his move, the winger took to social media to express his delight and introduce himself to his new supporters.
"I’m a Geordie now," he said.
"Happy to be here at this great club but more importantly I’m ready. Can’t wait to see you all.
"Let’s get to work! @nufc"
Elanga received a warm welcome from his new teammates with the likes of Alexander Isak and Joelinton commenting but among those was Greenwood, who offered his support with a clapping emoji.
In completing his move, Elanga will now be looking to stake his claim to be included in the Magpies' squad for the forthcoming Champions League campaign.

During his first interview with the club, he said: "I'm ready to put on this black and white top to really fight for this team and give everything for the passionate fanbase that lives and breathes football.
"I had an amazing two years at Nottingham Forest, they really helped me to become the player I am today, but I'm really happy to be here now.
"The club won a trophy last season and are building something unique, something special that I really want to be part of.
"I really want to buy into the culture, into the DNA of this club. I'm really happy to be here and I can't wait to get started."

headline: Bryan Mbeumo deal, striker signs, five sales - Man United's dream attack after transfer overhaul
body: Unless something drastic changes over the next week, those flocking to the Friends Arena in Stockholm to watch Manchester United's clash with Leeds United next Saturday will not have many new signings to feast their eyes on.
Despite making a flying start to this summer's window, announcing they had reached an agreement to sign Matheus Cunha 14 hours after it opened on June 1, progress has been slow at Old Trafford.
United have become bogged down in negotiations with Brentford over signing Bryan Mbeumo, meaning other objectives they want to try and complete this summer are yet to be properly explored.

The Reds have prioritised strengthening their attacking options after recording a negative goal difference for the second Premier League campaign running last term and the decision to commit £62.5million to the signing of Cunha has been applauded.

He scored 17 goals last season, meaning he will add a much-needed goal threat to United's attack. The club remains hopeful Mbeumo, who scored 20 Premier League goals in 2024/25, will soon join the Brazilian at Old Trafford.

However, United need to do more in the attacking department before the start of the season than just sign Mbeumo. With that said, MEN Sport has had a look at what deals United need to complete to revamp their forward line ahead of the big kick off.

As already documented, United are still striving to reach an agreement with Brentford to sign Mbeumo. The 25-year-old has been the subject of two offers from the Reds and the second - understood to be in excess of £60m - looked as though it would be enough.
Both United and Mbeumo are equally keen to get the deal done. The attacker informed Brentford at the beginning of June that he wants to move to M16.

It is widely believed United want to sign Mbeumo to install him as their right-sided No.10. Cunha is expected to operate as the left-sided No.10, meaning United are looking to give their attack a completely new look.

That, of course, is because the club remains determined to sign an out-and-out centre-forward. United need to invest in a reliable goalscorer this summer and the prospect of ending the summer without having recruited one could prove to be very costly.

Liam Delap was identified as United's primary striker target ahead of the start of the summer amid his £30m release clause at Ipswich Town, but he was snapped up by Chelsea. He held talks with United and other Premier League clubs before moving to Stamford Bridge.

Although missing out on Delap was not as big a blow as some suggested given he only has one full season of top flight football under his belt, it has had an impact on United's search for a No.9. They have been linked with the likes of Viktor Gyokeres, Victor Osimhen and several others, but they are not believed to have tabled a concrete offer for a goalscorer yet.
The problem United are facing, of course, is that they need to sell players to bring in new faces, and that has so far been easier said than done.
Missing out on Champions League qualification for 2025/26 has significantly reduced United's revenue streams, meaning they need to be smart this summer.

Having already spent £62.5m on Cunha and being prepared to spend possibly a little bit more on Mbeumo, United need to make their presence felt in the seller's market. Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony were identified as priority sales in May, while Alejandro Garnacho was informed he will be allowed to leave at the right price.

The quartet, alongside defender Tyrell Malacia, informed United last week they want to leave the club this summer to explore different opportunities, meaning both the players and the club are aligned in the direction they want to head in.
United value Rashford at £40m, Antony is available at £32.58m and Sancho is on offer for somewhere in the region of £20m-£25m. Garnacho is valued at north of £50m.

If United can command the aforementioned prices for those four players and get them off the books, it would go a long way towards boosting their chances of overseeing more incomings, both in attack and elsewhere in the squad.
Rasmus Hojlund, too, is not safe from the axe amid recent interest from Inter Milan. However, United may not be able to sanction an exit for him until they have the guarantee they can replace him.
Exits have never been so crucial at Old Trafford, meaning United need to hope and pray that clubs soon come knocking with offers.
No.10 options: Amad, Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount, Bruno Fernandes, Joshua Zirkzee, Matheus Cunha & Bryan Mbeumo.
No.9 options: Chido Obi, new striker.

headline: Bryan Mbeumo to Manchester United transfer latest as timeline emerges after Omar Berrada claim
body: Bryan Mbeumo will complete his transfer from Brentford to Manchester United in the coming week according to the latest reports, putting a lengthy saga to bed.

The Red Devils opened talks with their Premier League rivals regarding a move for the Bees' top goalscorer pver a month ago. They first saw a £55m offer rejected, a £60m offer was then placed, but still no agreement has been finalised amid claims Brentford are holding out for £70m.
Now, it is claimed the situation is about the change entirely, and with a quick resolution expected.
According to The Telegraph, Mbeumo 'is expected to arrive at United this week before the squad goes on tour with a breakthrough in negotiations expected in the coming days.'

This would certainly be a huge boost to manager Ruben Amorim, who will want the best part of his squad in place before they begin playing this pre-season after the original target of completing Mbeumo's signing before pre-season was not met.

United's stars, bar those who are seeking exits, returned to training earlier this week. Their first test is scheduled for one week's time on Saturday, July 19. That is against newly-promoted Leeds United in Stockholm, Sweden.

Amorim's men then continue their preparations in the United States. Three Premier League Summer Series fixtures await them across the Atlantic Ocean, against West Ham United (July 27), Bournemouth (July 31) and Everton (August 3).
And last up is an Old Trafford meeting with Serie A outfit Fiorentina (August 9), eight days before the season opener at home to Arsenal.

Should United make this anticipated 'breakthrough' and complete Mbeumo's signing this week, it will be beneficial as it gives the attacker a substantial amount of time to bed into new surroundings and create relationships with new teammates.
Matheus Cunha and defender Diego Leon have already come through the door so far this summer, but United need further additions if they want to avoid a repeat of last season.
"He [Matheus Cunha] was an important one to get done," chief executive Omar Berrada told United We Stand last month. "We're going to do our best to do more signings quickly.

"Sometimes when you're not quick, it's because you're negotiating and you're trying to make sure you get the right value for money. So being efficient or quick isn't necessarily the best thing for the club."

headline: Manchester United's biggest weakness is in danger of becoming even weaker - but they can fix it
body: Manchester United came flying out of the traps at the start of this summer's transfer window, confirming they had reached an agreement with Wolves to sign Matheus Cunha on June 1.

United had identified the Brazilian international as one of their top targets ahead of the start of the window and wasted no time in triggering his £62.5million release clause. The deal was officially finalised 11 days later.

After finishing the 2024/25 Premier League campaign with a negative goal difference of -10, United have rightly prioritised attacking signings this summer. They scored just 44 league goals last term and that was simply not good enough.
Having got Cunha, who is primed to become a shoo-in in the left-sided No.10 berth, through the door nice and early, United immediately switched their focus to signing Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo.

Despite tabling two offers for the Cameroonian, the second of which was in excess of £60m, United are still yet to make a breakthrough. Negotiations remain ongoing and some supporters are becoming restless.

Overhauling the attack is a leading priority for United this summer. In addition to landing Cunha and attempting to extract Mbeumo from the Gtech Community Stadium, they also want to sign a centre-forward.
The elephant in the room is that United need to sell players this summer in order to bring in new faces. With mid-July approaching, they are yet to oversee a sale.

United want to offload Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony this summer, while there is also no guarantee either Rasmus Hojlund or Joshua Zirkzee will still be at the club come the end of the window.

Rashford, Garnacho, Sancho and Antony have all informed United of their desire to leave and none of them have been involved in training at Carrington this week. Rashford has attended in the afternoons to do some individual training.

As natural wingers, the aforementioned quartet do not fit into Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system, meaning it is in United's best interests to sell them this summer and bank some much-needed cash. However, their current absences from the first-team squad means United are four bodies down.

Garnacho, despite being informed he can leave, was directly involved in 21 goals last season, scoring 11 and assisting ten. Rashford, prior to joining Aston Villa on loan in February, scored seven goals and provided three assists in the first half of the season.

United are quite right to try and sell Garnacho and Rashford this summer, likewise Sancho and Antony, who also both spent time away from Old Trafford on loan last season. However, with the four of them currently out of the picture and increasingly unlikely to revive their United careers should they not be offloaded, Amorim is light on attacking options.
Hojlund and Zirkzee got just 17 goals between them last term, highlighting the need for a centre-forward to be added to the ranks sooner rather than later.
Cunha, who scored 17 goals for Wolves last term, has added quality to United's attack, but it isn't enough. He needs to be joined by more new faces, but they are so far yet to appear.

With the clock ticking, United need to oversee some sales sooner rather than later. If they play their cards right, they could bank more than £140m for the four wantaway attackers, if they secure the prices they are looking for for each of them.

That, of course, is a far easier said than done task, and United still need to oversee a lot of improvements in the seller's market. However, if they can generate some much-needed funds by overseeing a crop of sales, they will be in a strong position to strengthen their attacking department in the way they dream of doing so.
After a flying start to the window, ongoing negotiations with Brentford has meant progress has slowed. However, there is still plenty of time left for them to make up for lost time.
Right now, though, there attack is looking even weaker than before.

headline: Omar Berrada has already explained why Manchester United will be patient amid Bryan Mbeumo delay
body: Manchester United chief executive Omar Berrada has already outlined why the club will require time to get new signings through the door this summer amid the ongoing Bryan Mbeumo saga.

Despite opening talks with Brentford more than a month a go, United are yet to reach an agreement with their Premier League counterparts for the Cameroon international, meaning some supporters are beginning to get increasingly frustrated.
United tabled an opening bid for Mbeumo in early-June, understood to be worth £55million, but it was swiftly rejected. They then made an improved offer in excess of £60m just over a fortnight ago.

It appeared as though that second bid was going to be enough for Brentford to give United the green light to complete a deal for the attacker. However, negotiations remain ongoing amid claims the Bees are holding out for around £70m.

United made a flying start to the window last month, announcing they had reached an agreement with Wolves to sign Matheus Cunha for £62.5m just 14 hours after the window had opened on June 1. However, the task was made easier by the fact Cunha had a release clause in his contract.

United have been unable to rely on a release clause in their attempts to sign Mbeumo, meaning discussions have now been ongoing for over a month. Both the Reds and the forward are equally keen to get a deal done.

However, with United desperate to strengthen in other areas this summer, they are at risk of losing time amid the length of time and effort it is taking to try and reach a breakthrough with Brentford.

After such a disappointing 2024/25 campaign, United desperately need to inject fresh blood into the squad this summer to give head coach Ruben Amorim the best possible chance of taking the club forward in the upcoming campaign. They want to sign a striker, a midfielder and a goalkeeper in addition to Mbeumo.

But with no European football to enjoy in 2025/26, revenue streams will be cut, meaning United are having to box clever. At the same time, though, they are having to tread a fine line between recruiting the right standard of players and not paying over the odds.
"He [Matheus Cunha] was an important one to get done," Berrada told United We Stand last month. "We're going to do our best to do more signings quickly.

"Sometimes when you're not quick, it's because you're negotiating and you're trying to make sure you get the right value for money. So being efficient or quick isn't necessarily the best thing for the club."
After getting a deal for Cunha wrapped in next to no time, United immediately increased expectation levels when their interest in Mbeumo surfaced just over 24 hours later.

They set a target of signing the former Troyes star in time for the start of pre-season training and they failed to achieve that ambition. But as Berrada explained, United want to ensure they get value for money - and that is fair game.

They have got to be smart this summer and that is the balancing act they are currently facing. United know just how desperate both the fans and Amorim are for new signings, but they can't lose sight of the finances despite that increasing hunger.

headline: New Mason Mount and Matheus Cunha partnership can unlock struggling Man United star
body: Mason Mount and Matheus Cunha won't have played together before, but the duo appear to be bonding and getting on well during Manchester United's first week of pre-season.

Most of Ruben Amorim's squad returned Carrington on Tuesday to begin training for the 2025/26 season, while the rest - all of whom were involved in international matches in June - were back on Thursday.

Mount and Cunha, who made the £62.5million move from Wolves last month, were among those to have returned first and the pair seem to be forming a friendship, despite only training together for a couple of days.

In fact, Mount posted an Instagram story of him and Cunha standing side-by-side during a training session earlier this week. Alongside that image, the ex-Chelsea man included the heart hands emoji and face exhaling emoji.

Should Mount and Cunha continue to bond, that could be a partnership that Amorim decides to use on a more frequent basis - and it could in fact unlock Rasmus Hojlund to get more opportunities in front of goal.

Mount joined the Reds in a £60m deal from Chelsea in 2023 but hasn't set the world alight, with the midfielder struggling with form and injuries. In fact, he started just six Premier League matches in 2024/25. He missed a sizeable chunk of the season after suffering two muscle injuries and was never able to get a consistent run in the XI.

When Mount is at his best, he can cause a real problem for opposition defences, there is no doubt about it. He can drift in between the midfield and the front line and feed passes through to United's forward players. As well as that, Mount has the potential to nick a goal or two here or there.

Amorim appears to like Mount and sees him as an important part of his United squad this season. Whether that is as a No.10 or a No.8, Mount can help unlock the best of Hojlund with his high creative potential.

The same, however, can be said about Cunha. The Brazilian created 57 chances in the Premier League last season - the 15th-highest in the division - and he has the potential to conjure up even more next term.

When both Mount and Cunha link-up, there is a high chance that either of them are going to create chances for their teammates to score. Having both of them on the pitch at the same time is no doubt going to boost Hojlund - and even Zirkzee - and his opportunities to score on a more regular basis.

headline: Man Utd suffer ‘latest blow’ as ‘bargain’ deal ‘close to completion’ amid decision to ‘snub’ Red Devils
body: According to reports, Manchester United have suffered their ‘latest blow’ as they are set to miss out on another summer transfer target.
This summer is vital for the Red Devils as they need to do plenty of business after finishing 15th in the Premier League and failed to win a trophy in 2024/25.

However, Man Utd have endured a frustrating start to this summer’s transfer window, with Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon their only signings. They are also struggling to offload their unwanted talents as Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho and Antony remain contracted to the Premier League giants.
In recent weeks, Ruben Amorim‘s side have been focused on signing Matheus Cunha, but this has turned into a prolonged battle as they are yet to meet Brentford’s asking price of around £65-70million.
Another priority for Man Utd is to sign a striker, but they have had to turn to alternative options after missing out on their preferred targets.
READ: Tough times for Premier League middle-class as old Big Six empire strikes back
United initially prioritised a move for Liam Delap and this deal looked likely, but the striker eventually decided to join Chelsea after they qualified for the Champions League.
Man Utd are also set to miss out on Viktor Gyokeres, with the 2025 top scorer in Europe contender making it clear that he prefers a move to Premier League rivals Arsenal.
It has been suggested that this could lead the Red Devils to turn to the free agent market for a new striker, with Juventus star Dusan Vlahovic mooted as an option.

The 25-year-old grabbed 17 goals and five assists in 44 appearances across all competitions during the 2024/25 campaign, but it has been reported that the Turin side are looking to get him off the books due to their financial difficulties.

Vlahovic is only under contract until 2026, but with bids yet to arrive, recent reports have indicated that the Serie A giants are considering cancelling his contract so he can be involved in a free transfer.
This represents a decent option for Man Utd, but The Sun claim they have suffered their ‘latest blow’ as ‘bargain striker’ Vlahovic’ is set to ‘snub’ the Premier League giants for AC Milan.
The report adds:
‘Sunsport understands that the Serbian forward favours a move to AC Milan, if he agrees a deal with Juventus to go their separate ways this summer.

‘The 25-year-old has been in the headlines for months, with United among a host of clubs reportedly monitoring his situation at Juventus. However, while United were thought to be favourites for his signature, Vlahovic is now set to stay in Italy.’
According to reports, Barcelona are under threat of being hijacked by another European giant in the race to sign Manchester United outcast Marcus Rashford.

headline: Tough times for Premier League middle-class as old Big Six empire strikes back
body: Very good chance we’re projecting a little bit here, but if there were a theme to this summer’s Premier League transfer business thus far it would be Okay, You’ve Had Your Fun.

Everyone enjoyed themselves, didn’t they, watching unlikely and less familiar teams compete for European spots? And everyone really enjoyed watching Tottenham and Manchester United be astonishing levels of sh*t for astonishing periods of time, right up until Spurs somehow unSpursed themselves at the best/worst possible moment.

But we get the impression now that it’s not just Spurs and United themselves spooked by last season’s ineptitude. Some of the other big clubs might have been hit by the realisation that this could happen to them if the Premier League’s middle-class weren’t brought to heel.

Let’s not pretend that the biggest clubs buying the best players from the other clubs in the league is a brand new phenomenon, but we’re not even at the middle of July yet and the heart has been ripped out of several of the upstarts who made last season so different.

And it’s the big clubs doing that ripping. Four of the traditional Big Six are currently Europe’s four biggest spenders this summer, and all of them have moved to take some of the best players from elsewhere.

Liverpool have Milos Kerkez. Chelsea have Joao Pedro. Tottenham have Mohammed Kudus, even if they have managed to Spurs their pursuit of Morgan Gibbs-White up. Man City have got themselves a Rayat Ait-Nouri.

Arsenal will be very much in the top five once they and Sporting stop their absurd game of chicken and just get a deal done for Viktor Gyokeres as we all know they eventually will once everyone can agree a way to proceed that allows everyone to feel like they’ve won. They’ve also got themselves a Christian Norgaard to continue the theme anyway.

Man United sneak into the top 10 as well after signing Wolves lunatic Matheus Cunha, and again the only reason they’re not higher is because Sir Jim Ratcliffe hasn’t yet decided precisely which and how many unimportant disposable meatbags he needs to sack to scrape together enough coppers to get himself a Bryan Mbeumo.

Is it too early to officially Fear for Brentford? We really think it might not be. They must have known the day would come that Thomas Frank tried his luck at somewhere bigger and also probably stupider, and he will certainly be doing those things.

One of the most interesting things we thought we might learn next season was just how good Frank is, and that this would involve not just what he did at Spurs but what Brentford did in his absence. How much of Brentford’s success has been down to him personally? How able is he to replicate that in a very, very different environment?

But Brentford appear to be about to take on that challenge in even more extreme circumstances than anyone could have imagined. They approach the dizzying uncertainty of life without their inspirational manager – and several members of his backroom staff – also without Norgaard, who did so much to make them tick, as well as almost certainly Mbeumo and quite possibly Yoane Wissa.

And promoting a manager from within represents an admirable but enormous gamble. The desire for some continuity may be understandable, but when you don’t have continuity of players we do wonder how prudent a move that actually is.

The good news for Brentford is that they are far from alone. Wolves have lost Cunha and Ait-Nouri. Brighton have lost Pedro. Forest are about to lose Anthony Elanga and Gibbs-White. Bournemouth have lost Kerkez and Dean Huijsen – even Real Madrid are helping out their big-club mates – while Palace will surely be stripped of some combination of Marc Guehi, Eberechi Eze, Adam Wharton and very likely the Europa League.

West Ham’s situation is slightly different, with the sanctioning of Kudus’ sale even to the worst possible place very likely a pretty smart, hard-headed decision to generate significant funds for their squad rebuild by offloading a player who doesn’t quite fit with the new manager’s plans. But it’s still another chastening reminder of how the land lies.

These clubs have all trod this path before and at least some of them will be absolutely fine and possibly even improve for smartly reinvesting that cash in new, cheaper players who go on to become the next big-money signings for the larger beasts.

Last season’s upsetting of the Premier League applecart came about in large part because the money sloshing around the Premier League is such that even the division’s proletariat now find themselves with spending power to outgun pretty much anyone outside the superclubs anywhere else.
But right now it’s an uncomfortable time for a lot of the Premier League’s middle-class as the old order seeks to re-establish itself at their enormous expense.

headline: Marcus Rashford receives dream move blow with Barcelona choosing ‘other options’
body: Marcus Rashford’s dream move to Barcelona may never materialise as the Spanish giants have reportedly selected an alternative, Ademola Lookman.
Rashford’s time at Manchester United is realistically over, but both he and the club are struggling to find an exit route.
The 27-year-old spent half of last season on loan at Aston Villa but has made it clear that he favours a move to Barcelona, with the Catalan club looking to strengthen their attacking depth.
Initially, it looked as if Rashford’s move would not come to be with Barceloan going all out to sign Nico Williams, only for the 22-year-old to go sign a ten-year deal with Athletic Bilbao.
Rashford then would have been hopeful about his chances, but a report from Spain suggests Barcelona are going after an alternative, former Everton winger Lookman.
Sport, a newspaper based in Barcelona, says head coach Hansi Flick ‘likes’ the 27-year-old and that he could be available for less than €50 million.

“The Blaugrana have other options on the table, such as Rafa Leao, and are also reportedly keeping a close eye on the situation of Atalanta star Ademola Lookman,” journalist Lluis Miguelsanz said. “He’s a player Flick likes, but his situation isn’t encouraging because relations with his entourage are currently strained.
“Lookman has been trying for years to make the big leap from Atalanta to a top-flight Champions League club, but so far no one has taken the step to sign him.

“The Italian club took a chance by signing him from Leipzig for €10 million, and he’s exploded onto the scene. He’s been gaining international prominence and is now a more mature player, although he needs to take a definitive step to establish himself at the elite level, as his performance is still very inconsistent.

“He’s a pure winger, fast and capable of scoring goals. And he can play in all attacking positions, something Barça highly valued in Luis Díaz, the leading candidate to fill that position if financially possible. Atalanta would be willing to negotiate his sale for less than €50 million because his contract expires in 2027 and he hasn’t renewed yet, and Tottenham are strongly interested in signing him.”
One stumbling block, though, could be Lookman’s choice of agency and their involvement with an ongoing issue at Barcelona.
“The major handicap is that Lookman shares a representation agency with Marc-André ter Stegen, and problems with the goalkeeper are brewing.

“The German will push hard to stay at Barça, and this could create an awkward situation for all parties, which could significantly impact relations with Lookman’s entourage. For now, Barça only has information about his situation, like that of many wingers, but nothing has been done about it.”
Meanwhile, transfer reporter Fabrizio Romano says Rashford is “very open” to the Barcelona move and is “basically waiting for Barca.”

“Marcus Rashford would be very keen on a move to Barcelona. Marcus Rashford is very open to that opportunity. I always told you since January and I keep repeating that Rashford would love Barca move and he’s basically waiting for Barca move because he has many opportunities.
“Rashford is losing the number 10. He was informed 24 hours before about that, through his agents of course, but let me say that it’s not just Marcus Rashford desire to leave Manchester United.

“All of this also starts from Manchester United desire to part ways from Marcus Rashford since January and continuing this summer. So it’s not only Rashford who wants to leave United but there is also United who are pushing the opportunity to sell Marcus Rashford or to find a solution for him this summer.
“When I say Man United it’s the management, it’s the coach Ruben Amorim. So all parties are going to the same direction for Marcus Rashford to leave.”

headline: Man Utd transfer hint? Door swings open for Amorim to land replacement for flop he ‘wants out’
body: Man Utd could have a chance of signing Emiliano Martinez this summer as Aston Villa prepare to announce a new goalkeeper signing, according to reports.
The Red Devils had a nightmare season in the Premier League with Ruben Amorim’s side finishing 15th in the table and failed to qualify for Europe.
Man Utd had a last-gasp chance to qualify for next season’s Champions League but blew it when they lost 1-0 to Tottenham in the Europa League final.
Despite their awful season, INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe have decided to stick with Amorim as they provide summer support for transfers.
They want to give the former Sporting CP head coach with the tools to be able to implement his style of play effectively and they will back him in the transfer market.
Man Utd have already brought in Wolves forward Matheus Cunha for £62.5m as they look to improve his attack, while Brentford’s Bryan Mbeumo is another player they have made a bids for.

The Red Devils need to improve all over the pitch ahead of next season but one player who has come in for lots of criticism this season is goalkeeper Andre Onana.
There were rumours earlier this year that Amorim now ‘wants him out’ of Old Trafford and is looking for a new goalkeeper before next season.
And now Argentina international Martinez – who has been brilliant for Aston Villa over the past five years – has been linked with a summer move to Old Trafford.
Both Martinez and Leon Bailey were in tears at the end of Aston Villa’s 2-0 win over Tottenham at the end of the season, leading to speculation that both players could be leaving in the summer.
Responding to those rumours, Aston Villa boss Unai Emery did little to persuade journalists otherwise, he said: “Of course, it is the last match (of the season) here, and I don’t know.

“We will see about the team, the players, but of course, they are responding on the field, at the moment they are responding and they are so, so focused in how we are preparing and playing each match.
“Of course, Leon Bailey is playing now less because other players are responding very well. They are performing well.”
And now the Daily Mirror claim that Aston Villa are ‘closing in on goalkeeper transfer’ in an ‘exit hint’ for Martinez with Dutch goalkeeper Marco Bizot set to arrive.
Bizot, who is a full Netherlands international, is set to arrive from French club Brest and is ‘keen to play in the Premier League and ready for a new challenge’.

It is understood that Aston Villa boss Emery is ‘looking for a new keeper with uncertainty over Argentina keeper Martinez’s long term future’ with Man Utd mentioned as wanting the Argentina international.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Man Utd to get top striker for free? Forest fuming over leak
body: Jordan Henderson is heading to London, while Barcelona have decided to give Marcus Rashford the move he craves. But can they give Manchester United what they want?
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Khvicha Kvaratskhelia – PSG to Liverpool
The story goes that Liverpool will ‘consider’ a move for Kvaratskhelia if they receive a ‘substantially’ better offer from Barca or Bayern for Luis Diaz, who they see as ‘a more proven player’ than the Georgian star, who only joined PSG in January before winning the lot. We know we ought to be more mature and offer a more considered response, but all we’ve got is: Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha.

19) 🔽 Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Arsenal
Arsenal, finally, appear to have chosen a lane, one that takes them to Gyokeres’ door. We would never rule out a sharp U-turn, but Sesko’s hopes of joining Arsenal this summer have never seemed as slim as they appear right now.

18) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
Despite speculation that Juve preferred a permanent move for Francisco Conceicao, many reports suggest a deal has been agreed with United and it’s now down to Sancho to decide if how much he might be prepared to sacrifice to kickstart his career. The signs so far: not much…

17) 🔼 Dusan Vlahovic – Juventus to Manchester United
Juve’s problem here is similar to United’s with Sancho: they owe the player another year of a huge salary. But Vlahovic may be prepared to forego it if Juve simply cut him loose and allow him to find a contract elsewhere as a free-agent. Which would certainly suit United.

16) Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
With a year left on his contract and a renewal unlikely, Palace are willing to cash in on their captain – but Liverpool won’t pay the £50million or so the Eagles are demanding. Currently, we are at stalemate. Liverpool don’t seem twitchy yet, but they are keeping the lines of communication open.

15) 🆕 Yoane Wissa – Brentford to Nottingham Forest
Brentford won’t sell Wissa and Mbeumo, which surely means Forest’s failed bid for the former will give Manchester United a kick up the backside in their pursuit of the latter…right?

14) 🔽 Cristhian Mosquera – Valencia to Arsenal
Arsenal had one bid rejected for the 2024 Golden Boy-shortlisted defender but they remain in talks with Valencia. Which don’t appear to be going well.

13) 🔽 Sean Longstaff – Newcastle to Leeds
Ah. It was initially thought Newcastle had accepted what was thought to be Leeds’ best and final offer, worth £10million plus add-ons, but it seems not. The Toon clearly feel they can squeeze more out of Leeds. Though probably not the £50million Man Utd were once quoted by Mike Ashley.

12) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Arsenal have met with Eze’s representatives and the player is said to be keen on the prospect of moving to the Emirates. Arsenal’s next call ought to be to Palace, who will tell the Gunners they expect Eze’s £67.5million release clause to be paid in full, not as a part-exchange deal involving players we can’t be sure actually exist.

11) Djordje Petrovic – Chelsea to Bournemouth
Sunderland have expressed an interest in signing Petrovic, who impressed on loan at Strasbourg last season, but it’s Bournemouth who are in the driving seat. Andoni Iraola needs a new goalkeeper and his side have made an offer, according to Fabrizio Romano, who says the Serbian goalkeeper is ‘keen on the move’. You can’t blame him; it’s an opportunity to become the No.1 at a mid-table Premier League team.

10) 🔼 Marcus Rashford – Manchester United to Barcelona
With Nico Williams signing a new contract with Athletic Bilbao and Liverpool ignoring interest in Luis Diaz, Rashford is said to have found himself at the top of Barca’s wish-list and the Catalans are ready to go ‘all in’. Unfortunately for Barca – and United – ‘all’ doesn’t amount to much these days. Rashford wants the move and, most likely, United will be paying him to play as a loanee at the Nou Camp next season.

9) Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
United were confident of getting a deal done before now, with a big chunk of Ruben Amorim’s squad due back for pre-season on July 7, but still we wait. The beauty of missing your own deadline is you can simply set another. And another if need be. The latest guess for when United want Mbeumo on board is July 22 when they fly off to the United States.

8) 🔼 Darwin Nunez – Liverpool to Napoli
Napoli are ready to pay £43million plus about £4.4million for Nunez, who will be offered £100k a week after tax, which represents a slight raise on what he trousers at Anfield. Liverpool might get more from Saudi but, wisely, the Kop’s Captain Chaos prefers to stay in Europe for now. That Galatasaray are now ready to meet Napoli’s demands for Victor Osimhen ought to speed this up.

7) James Trafford – Burnley to Newcastle
This has been going on for over a year but Newcastle are likely to get this done – finally – once the two clubs stop faffing and agree on all the T&Cs around a £30million deal.

6) 🔽 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Arsenal
So many claims and counter claims now, we’ve almost given up trying to keep up. The latest: Arsenal have offered £56million, with £4.3million then £8.6million in add-ons, which could take the total to £69million. But Sporting aren’t interested in bonuses; they are insisting on £60million up front. Just pay it, FFS, Arsenal and complete that jigsaw. They will. We think. Won’t they?

5) 🔼 Evan Ferguson – Brighton to Roma
After a loan spell at West Ham in which he did absolutely nothing, Ferguson is now mulling over an opportunity to join Roma on loan, with some claiming the Italians will retain the option to buy. Sounds like a great opportunity for a striker once rated at £100million to kickstart his stalling career.

3) 🆕 Jordan Henderson – Ajax to Brentford
No romantic return to Sunderland, who are a bit busy signing everyone else, Henderson is reportedly close to signing for Brentford to replace Arsenal new boy Christian Norgaard. Thomas Tuchel will be chuffed, and so will Arne Slot, since Henderson will probably refuse to tackle any Liverpool player out of #respect.

2) 🔼 Noni Madueke – Chelsea to Arsenal
Chelsea have agreed a fee with Arsenal – £52m, says Orny – and the winger has been given permission to fly back before the Club World Cup final to have a medical with the Gunners. Which will prompt some screeching U-turns among the Arsenal fan base, you would expect.

1) 🔼 Anthony Elanga – Nottingham Forest to Newcastle
Newcastle have finally reached an agreement with Forest worth £52million plus add-ons and Elanga is apparently in the North-East for a medical.
